content: AUTHORIZATION TO CONVEY THE SURFACE ESTATE OF THE SAN JACINTO DISPOSAL AREA IN GALVESTON, TEXAS. The Energy and Water Development Appropriations Act, 1994 is amended to authorize the Secretary of the Army to convey the surface estate of a 605-acre parcel of land known as the San Jacinto Disposal Area to the city of Galveston, Texas. The conveyance is subject to agreement on compensation between the Secretary and the city. Upon receipt of compensation, the Secretary will convey the Disposal Area surface estate. The Energy and Water Development Appropriations Act, 1994 authorizes the Secretary of the Army to convey the surface estate of a 605-acre parcel of land known as the San Jacinto Disposal Area to the city of Galveston, Texas, subject to compensation agreement. If the full Disposal Area surface estate is conveyed, compensation includes conveyance of a 564-acre parcel on Pelican Island, Texas, and payment equal to the difference in fair market value between the Disposal Area and Pelican Island surface estates. The Energy and Water Development Appropriations Act, 1994 authorizes the Secretary of the Army to convey the surface estate of a 605-acre parcel of land known as the San Jacinto Disposal Area to the city of Galveston, Texas. If the conveyance is 125 acres or less, compensation shall be equal to the fair market value of the part of the Disposal Area surface estate to be conveyed. Costs of maintaining the Galveston Harbor and Channel will continue to be governed by the Local Cooperation Agreement. Upon conveyance of the Disposal Area surface estate, the Department of the Army shall be compensated for the total costs incurred for disposal of dredge material and site preparation. The fair market value of the Disposal Area surface estate and Pelican Island surface estate is determined by independent appraisers. The Disposal Area surface estate may be declared nonnavigable waters if projects are not in the public interest, subject to certain limits and regulatory requirements. The Disposal Area surface estate must be bulkheaded or filled with permanent structures, including marina facilities, to comply with federal regulations. Failure to do so within 5 years of permits issuance will result in the expiration of nonnavigability declaration for that area. The Disposal Area and Pelican Island surface estates must be surveyed and legally described before conveyance.
